content.description: Use some underwater rocks to get on, then slap your way up the route. If you can't find a hold just keep slapping up higher on slopers.
content.location: To the left of the point under a free standing rock sitting on top.

content.description: Start- right hand in finger pocket undercling hold, left hand in finger pocket around the arete. First move left hand to jug then bring right hand around the corner to another jug. Crux move is semi-dynamic to left hand side-pull. Pull yourself around the corner then top-out. FA with no shoes so the grade might be a little off. Not sure how high the water level was when I climbed this so depending on the day it might be completely submerged or very difficult to access.
content.location: (from the water) around the corner right of slapper, past the crevice in the corner. Starts at the first overhanging section past the corner crevice.

content.description: So easy you could do this route in flip flops. This is the easiest way to get to the top of the small cliff to jump off it. Water level is good, just be careful with it being a slab.
content.location: Right to the left of the cliff that sticks out the most at the point. Take the obvious crack going straight up.

content.description: A slab wall with a perfect easy crack route and potential for more difficult routes. This wall is perfect when the water level is full or a little less than full. The water is at least 20 feet deep here. Once you get to the top, there are a few good cliff jumping spots on the point.
